author: By Alexis Soloski
title: The One Without Matthew Perry
description: Even as he struggled with drug and alcohol addiction, the “Friends” star Matthew Perry, who died at the age of 54, made it all look easy.
content: A confession: When I received a news alert that the actor Matthew Perry had died, my mind adopted the particular cadence that Perry perfected as Chandler Bing, the character he played for 10 seasons on the NBC sitcom “Friends.” Here is what I thought, “Could this be any sadder?”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: After Mexico Hurricane, a Frantic Hunt for Food, Water and Loved Ones
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, October 29, 2023.
content: “They loot because they want to eat.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Goldman and Gal Koplewitz
title: Israel’s Hidden Victims, Arab Bedouins, Were Attacked by Hamas Too
description: At least 17 died in the Hamas attacks, and many more in the impoverished community have since lost their livelihoods in Jewish farms that were ransacked.
content: During their murderous Oct. 7 rampage, Hamas militants attacked Zikkim Beach near the Gaza Strip where Abd Alrahman Aatef Ziadna and his family had been camping along the coast of the Mediterranean Sea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: Joe Biden Knows What He’s Doing
description: The combination of tragedy, confusion and cost is what makes leadership so difficult.
content: There’s a gathering sense that President Biden’s response to the war in Gaza may cost him the 2024 election. A recent Gallup poll showed that his support among Democrats has slipped 11 points in the past month to 75 percent, the lowest of his presidency. On Friday my colleagues in the newsroom reported on a growing backlash against Biden coming from young and left-leaning voters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Monday Briefing: Israel Extends Gaza Ground Campaign
description: Plus as the world ages, Africa blooms with youth.
content: The Israeli military yesterday signaled a heavier assault on Gaza and warned with increasing “urgency” that Palestinian civilians should move to the southern part of the coastal Gaza Strip.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Nazis in Canada? A Secret List With Answers May Soon Be Released.
description: A report from an inquiry into possible war criminals in Canada has been kept from the public for almost 40 years.
content: For 37 years, Canada has kept close guard on an explosive roster of names.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: A Less Polarized Poland? Not Yet, Election Results Suggest.
description: On whatever side they stand, many voters say they yearn for a more united nation. But after a brutal campaign, divisions — between left and right, urban and rural, young and old — remain stark.
content: Three years apart in age, the brother and sister grew up in a tiny village in eastern Poland, helping out on the family farm and going to church each Sunday under pressure from their parents.
source.name: The New York Times

title: An Anti-Obesity Drug and Cultural Stigmas
description: Readers discuss a column by Tressie McMillan Cottom. Also: Insights into Republican voters; a scandal at Liberty University; free analysis?
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Review: An Opera About Drones Brings a Pilot’s War Home
description: Jeanine Tesori and George Brant’s “Grounded,” which Washington National Opera premiered on Saturday, is headed to the Metropolitan Opera next year.
content: The young mezzo-soprano Emily D’Angelo has a wide grin, haunted eyes and a mellow, confident voice that flashes with lean anxiety. In tone and presence, she’s driven, intense, wry. Onstage she’s unsentimental — and unsettled.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Decided I Needed a Slice of Junior’s Strawberry Cheesecake’
description: A long trip to satisfy a craving, a Greenwich Village walk and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: Obama’s Presidential Center Is Rising, Finally, in Chicago
description: The city beat out others to host Barack Obama’s presidential center. But as construction continues on the South Side, some residents fear being priced out.
content: More than eight years have passed since Barack Obama proclaimed that his presidential center would be built on Chicago’s South Side, where he got his start as a community organizer and politician.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Casey, Jack D'Isidoro, Aaron Esposito, John Woo, Sophia Lanman and Quinton Kamara
title: The Sunday Read: ‘Who Hired the Hitmen to Silence Zitácuaro?’
description: In one small Mexican city, journalists who tried to expose cartel violence and government corruption became swept up in the murders devouring the country.
content: On Oct. 19, 2021, Armando Linares López was writing up notes from an interview when his cellphone buzzed with an unknown number. Linares, 49 and stocky with black hair that was just starting to show gray streaks, ran an online news site in a small Mexican city called Zitácuaro. He knew his beat so intimately that calls from unfamiliar phone numbers were rare.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Sheffield
title: Dylan’s Back Pages, and Then Some
description: This collection of archival treasures at the Bob Dylan Center includes fan mail from Paul McCartney and Bruce Springsteen.
content: In 2016, the world learned that a new Bob Dylan Center was coming to Tulsa, Okla. Dylan said, “I’m glad that my archives, which have been collected all these years, have finally found a home and are to be included with the works of Woody Guthrie and especially alongside all the valuable artifacts from the Native American Nations.” “Bob Dylan: Mixing Up the Medicine” is the center’s official publication, a lavishly illustrated collection of archival treasures, edited by Mark Davidson and Parker Fishel. It also has new essays by a host of Dylan scholars, from artists like Ed Ruscha, Richard Hell and Lee Ranaldo to writers like Greil Marcus, Joy Harjo, Michael Ondaatje and Amanda Petrusich.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: A New Place to Learn Civics: The Workplace
description: Fearing that rising distrust could spell doom for businesses, some companies are offering employees lessons in democracy.
content: A peaceful end to the war in Ukraine. That was the wish behind a post that Simge Krüger made on LinkedIn in March.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Colleagues and Friends Mourn Actor Matthew Perry
description: Fans and celebrities paid tribute to Perry, who died at age 54 on Saturday.
content: Celebrities, actors and entertainment and political leaders shared tributes to Matthew Perry, who starred on the hit television series “Friends” and died on Saturday at the age of 54.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chang W. Lee and Inyoung Kang
title: One Year After Tragedy, a Subdued Halloween in Itaewon
description: The authorities in Seoul were out in force over the weekend, but the crowds in the typically bustling neighborhood were sparse.
content: Seoul marked a somber anniversary over the weekend, a year after nearly 160 people died in a crowd surge in Itaewon, a popular nightlife district in the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hussam Abu Safyia
title: I’m a Pediatrician in Gaza. Please Save Us From This Horror.
description: There is still hope we can avoid the worst outcomes.
content: At Kamal Adwan Hospital in northern Gaza, we are no strangers to treating victims of airstrikes over the years. The team all too often must rush into the emergency room, all hands on deck, ready to treat shrapnel wounds, burns and blood loss. In the early days of the current Israel-Hamas conflict, our hospital of only 80 beds was quickly overrun. On Oct. 17, following the explosion at Al-Ahli Arab Hospital in Gaza City, we were flooded with dozens of wounded and dying victims. By the next day, our patient roster had grown by nearly 120. We knew it would be another sleepless night, another in a string of far too many since the violence started 10 days earlier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Root
title: From Smugglers and TikTok, Migrants Get a Message: Go to New York
description: Many migrants entering the U.S. southern border have been steered to New York City by relatives, politicians and smugglers, in part because of the city’s right-to-shelter policy.
content: Mohamed was well along a zigzag journey from his native Mauritania in West Africa, not knowing precisely where he would wind up, and not caring — just as long as it was somewhere in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Primary Battles Brew Over Progressive Democrats’ Stances on Israel
description: Representative Summer Lee of Pennsylvania, who joined calls for a cease-fire, has become one of several progressive lawmakers facing new pressure from primary challengers.
content: As Congregation Beth Shalom in Pittsburgh observed a special evening of prayer on Oct. 22 for the Israeli captives in Gaza, Representative Summer Lee, the progressive Democrat whose district includes the synagogue, paid her respects. She was late to arrive and could not stay long, but the rabbi, Seth Adelson, called her chief of staff the next day to offer his thanks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sonja Anderson
title: The City That Never Sleeps … or Shops in Person
description: New York is clogged with packages ordered by residents who buy online far more than they need to.
content: Walking through New York City — America’s great harborer of people, culture and activity — can feel like strolling the world’s largest outdoor mall. Opportunities to acquire are everywhere, waiting either around the corner or at the end of a subway ride: exotic foods, knickknacks, records, books, medicine, tents, computers, sunglasses and everything else. It’s difficult to imagine a product one can’t buy in Manhattan, let alone the boroughs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronen Bergman, Mark Mazzetti and Maria Abi-Habib
title: How Years of Israeli Failures on Hamas Led to a Devastating Attack
description: Israeli officials completely underestimated the magnitude of the Oct. 7 attacks by Hamas, shattering the country’s once invincible sense of security.
content: It was 3 a.m. on Oct. 7, and Ronen Bar, the head of Israel’s domestic security service, still could not determine if what he was seeing was just another Hamas military exercise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bittel
title: These Tiny, Beautiful Wasps Eat the Hearts Out of Cockroaches
description: Jewel wasps carve up cockroaches like jack-o’-lanterns in a way scientists have never seen before.
content: If you loathe cockroaches, you’re going to love the emerald jewel wasp.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: As Fighting Rages, Ukraine Takes Its Battle to the Diplomatic Arena
description: A forum in Malta was intended to encourage countries that have taken a neutral stance on the invasion of Ukraine not to side with Russia.
content: Dozens of countries met for a second day on Sunday at a forum in Malta intended to rally support for Ukraine and to encourage countries in Africa, Latin America and Asia that have taken a neutral stance in the conflict there not to side with Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Colter Walls
title: Back-to-Back Premieres Defy a Season of Leaner Offerings
description: Institutions are cutting back, but in corners of the city there is still new music to be found, like song cycles by Ted Hearne and Paul Pinto.
content: New York classical music institutions are in a period of economic challenges. This season, the Metropolitan Opera is dark more nights than in the past. At the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the historic Next Wave Festival is a shadow of its former self.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Studios Said to See Progress in Talks With Striking Actors
description: The entertainment companies are growing optimistic that the work stoppage may end soon, though some issues remain unresolved, people briefed on the matter said.
content: Following several productive days at the negotiating table, Hollywood studios are growing optimistic that they are getting closer to a deal to end the 108-day actors’ strike, according to three people briefed on the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: ‘S.N.L.’ Elects Another President Biden
description: Mikey Day made his debut as the president in an episode that was hosted by the comic Nate Bargatze and featured Christopher Walken as the Spirit of Halloween.
content: Mikey Day became the latest “Saturday Night Live” cast member to take a turn at playing President Biden in an opening sketch that was nominally about a Halloween celebration at the White House, but was also a satirical commentary on whether or not Americans should have concerns about the president’s age.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter
title: The Rigid World of French Cheesemaking Meets Unbound Climate Change
description: Reams of rules govern how the best French cheeses are made, but hotter, drier summers may unshackle struggling producers.
content: Just past the neat vineyards and country houses with their blue shutters and tile roofs, goats munch their way through a field of thigh-high plants more typical to Sudan and India than Southern France.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: Maine Sheriff Says He Sent Statewide Alert About Gunman Last Month
description: The sheriff said the gunman had made threats against the Army base where he was assigned, prompting an alert to all law enforcement agencies in the state weeks before the mass shooting.
content: A sheriff in Maine says he sent an alert to all law enforcement agencies in the state last month after learning that an Army reservist had made threats against his base, a notification that came weeks before the reservist fatally shot 18 people in America’s deadliest mass shooting this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: Maine Gunman Disclosed He Had Mental Health Issues, Gun Shop Owner Says
description: The man sought to purchase a gun silencer in August but was denied after self-reporting mental health issues on a federal form, the gun store owner said.
content: Nearly three months before Robert R. Card II fatally shot 18 people in Lewiston, Maine, a gun shop declined to let him complete his purchase of a firearm silencer after he disclosed on a form that he had mental health issues, the shop’s owner said in an interview Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bruce Weber
title: Robert Brustein, Passionate Force in Nonprofit Theater, Dies at 96
description: A critic and dramatist himself, he started repertory companies at Yale and Harvard and fiercely defended the art form, even if it meant feuding with playwrights.
content: Robert Brustein, an erudite and contentious advocate for profit-indifferent theater, in the service of which he wore many hats — critic, teacher, producer, director, playwright and even actor — died on Sunday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 96.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger and Natan Odenheimer
title: They Refused to Serve. Now They’re Supporting Israel’s War Effort.
description: The Brothers in Arms group helped lead protests against the government, with members vowing to ignore military call-ups. But after the Hamas attacks, it pivoted to aid those affected by the conflict.
content: Made up largely of veterans and reservists, the group that calls itself Brothers in Arms started nine months ago as a protest movement against the government of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. It helped to organize giant weekly demonstrations against his plans to give the government unprecedented control over the judiciary. And many of its members vowed that they would not serve in the army if called.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: In Kenya, King Charles Will ‘Walk a Tightrope’ on Britain’s Past
description: More candid than his mother, he is likely to acknowledge the monarchy’s brutal colonial history but avoid inviting calls for reparations.
content: When King Charles III travels to Kenya this week, it will be a journey steeped in family memory for Britain’s new monarch: In 1952, his mother, Elizabeth, had just spent the night at Treetops, a remote Kenyan game-viewing lodge, when she learned of the death of her father, George VI, which thrust her onto the throne.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: How California Became America’s Contemporary Music Capital
description: On the eve of a sprawling new festival, John Adams, Esa-Pekka Salonen, Gustavo Dudamel and others recount how the state reinvigorated classical music.
content: Nobody will be able to take in the entire California Festival, a statewide series of classical music events spanning 650 miles with such density that some nights will have 10 or more performances happening at once.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko, Marc Santora, Isabel Kershner and Riley Mellen
title: Mob storms plane arriving in Russia from Tel Aviv, authorities say.
description: The Russian authorities announced that the airport in Makhachkala, the capital of the predominantly Muslim Dagestan region, was temporarily closed and riot police were dispatched to the scene.
content: A mob stormed an airport in southern Russia where a commercial flight from Tel Aviv had arrived on Sunday night, according to Russian state media and videos posted from the scene. The episode followed several anti-Israel protests in the region that could signal a new point of friction for the Kremlin as it wages a war in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Film Based on Horror-Survival Video Game Is Surprise Box Office Hit
description: “Five Nights at Freddy’s,” which sold an estimated $78 million in tickets at North American theaters, reinforced moviegoers’ desire for something other than a sequel.
content: An evil pizzeria mascot, Freddy Fazbear, became a surprise box office sensation over the weekend, reinforcing a message that moviegoers have been sending to Hollywood all year: Give us something new.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Vognar
title: The Day Disco Was Demolished
description: “The War on Disco,” a new PBS documentary, explores the backlash against the genre and the issues of race, gender and sexuality that informed it.
content: The plan was simple enough: Gather a bunch of disco records, put them in a crate and blow them to smithereens in between games of a doubleheader between the Chicago White Sox and Detroit Tigers at Comiskey Park. What could possibly go wrong?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo
title: Eyedrops From Major Brands May Cause Infection, F.D.A. Says
description: Target, CVS and Rite Aid are pulling products from shelves after federal investigators found unsanitary conditions and recommended a recall.
content: Federal health officials are advising consumers to stop using more than two dozen over-the-counter eyedrops products because of a potential risk of eye infection that may lead to partial vision loss or blindness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josh Ocampo
title: A Critic With Monsters on His Mind
description: The scariest part of Erik Piepenburg’s job as a reporter who covers horror movies? Films that fail to frighten him.
content: Some 10-year-olds might shield their eyes while watching a horror movie. But at that age, Erik Piepenburg was glued to the screen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: A Chill in the Air and Chili in Your Pot
description: Turkey chili, chili con carne, black bean chili with mushrooms, white bean chili with lamb — our chili collection is comprehensive comfort.
content: Good morning. Chili season gets underway in my house after the first day I am well and truly chilled on my daily bike ride north along the harbor, wind whistling out of the west as if to knock me over. That sure wasn’t yesterday, not in New York!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Dunlap
title: A Seal of Recognition
description: A postage stamp issued in 2020 commemorated Gwen Ifill, a New York Times correspondent who covered the White House in the early ’90s.
content: New York Times journalists have received many honors. But recognition by way of U.S. postage stamps has proved elusive. It seems that only two people closely associated with The Times have been the subjects of commemorative stamps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: The Devil’s Bargain Mike Pence Could Not Escape
description: The former vice president tied himself to Donald Trump in the 2016 campaign and it may have cost him a political future.
content: The decision by Mike Pence to end his presidential campaign on Saturday was a bow to what had finally become inevitable. He was struggling to raise money, win support from the party’s base and manage the torments from the man who had made him nationally famous, Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Oct. 30, 2023
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: ‘A Communal Sigh of Relief’: Emerging From Lockdown, Lewiston Gathers to Mourn
description: Residents in and around the city, no longer under lockdowns, spent the weekend coming together to mourn, share meals and prepare to bury their dead.
content: For the two days after a gunman killed 18 people and injured 13 in Lewiston, Patrick Hynes and other residents in Southern Maine sat in their own homes, under a shelter-in-place order, facing their grief, their rage, in isolation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Egner
title: Watch Matthew Perry’s Best Performances
description: Perry will always be remembered as Chandler Bing. But he had a long and varied career that included films and many other series.
content: Matthew Perry, who died Saturday at 54, was one of the biggest TV stars of the past three decades thanks to his role on “Friends,” the blockbuster NBC sitcom that continues to be enormously popular in the streaming era.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: Please, Israel, Don’t Get Lost in Hamas’s Tunnels
description: It’s time for Israel to consider a cease-fire.
content: I am watching the Israel-Hamas war in Gaza today and thinking about one of the world leaders I’ve most admired: Manmohan Singh. He was India’s prime minister in late November 2008, when 10 Pakistani jihadist militants from the Lashkar-e-Taiba group, widely believed to be linked to Pakistan’s military intelligence, infiltrated India and killed more than 160 people in Mumbai, including 61 people at two luxury hotels. What was Singh’s military response to India’s Sept. 11?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abu Bakr Bashir, Iyad Abuheweila, Vivian Nereim and Yousur Al-Hlou
title: 34 Hours of Fear: The Blackout That Cut Gaza Off From the World
description: As Israeli forces entered Gaza on Friday to fight Hamas, phone and internet service was severed, sowing chaos for Palestinian civilians and leaving rescuers driving blindly toward explosions.
content: For 34 hours, the vast majority of the more than two million Palestinians who live in Gaza had no way to reach the outside world, or one another.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amir Jina, Jesse Anttila-Hughes and Gordon McCord
title: El Niños Are Predictable. We Should Prepare for Their Possibly Disastrous Consequences.
description: Rich countries must deepen their assistance to developing countries in the path of the weather pattern.
content: As we head toward winter, the good news for those who shiver at the thought of cold weather is that temperatures are likely to be warmer for people who live in the nation’s northern tier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Colombia Mobilizes Troops to Search for Kidnapped Father of Liverpool Player
description: The parents of Luis Díaz, a Colombian star of the English club, were both kidnapped on Saturday. His mother was rescued hours later, but his father remains missing.
content: The authorities in Colombia have mobilized the national police and the military to look for the father of the soccer star Luis Díaz, a Colombian standout for the English club Liverpool whose parents were kidnapped in his hometown on Saturday. Given soccer’s popularity here, the incident captured the South American country’s attention, but it also stoked fears of increasing insecurity in a nation where such kidnappings were becoming less common until a surge in recent years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling and Brooks Barnes
title: Reaction to Hamas Attack Leaves Some Jews in Hollywood Feeling Unmoored
description: The response to the Oct. 7 assault, and to Israel’s retaliation, has revealed a schism in the entertainment world that many did not realize was there.
content: With the exception of the rare conservative, Hollywood has long seemed to exist in an ideological bubble — a bastion of progressive politics, where Jewish people have thrived, Democratic politicians have been celebrated and stars have espoused liberal ideas from the Oscar stage and rushed to support movements like Black Lives Matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Light on a Night Stand
description: Kenneth Cortes makes a glowing New York Times debut.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Netanyahu Finds Himself at War in Gaza and at Home
description: Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, apologized for accusing military and security officials of lapses that led to the Hamas massacre but declined to accept responsibility himself.
content: The social media post went up online at 1:10 a.m. Sunday, while most Israelis were sleeping.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: What’s on TV This Week: BravoCon and a Classic Rom-Com
description: Andy Cohen’s annual convention airs on Bravo, and HBO plays “Definitely, Maybe.”
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Oct. 30-Nov. 5. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Morning Team
title: Israeli Troops in Gaza
description: The war’s “next stage” has started.
content: Israel announced it will attack Gaza from the air, land and sea, expanding its war against Hamas days after its tanks began an intense ground operation. The military again urged civilians to move south as troops have entered Gaza from the north (see where troops crossed the border).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenna Russell and Kieran Kesner
title: Halloween Headaches in Salem, Mass.: Traffic. Crowds. Tiny Liquor Bottles?
description: Miniature bottles of alcohol known as “nips” litter gardens, parks and playgrounds, prompting the Witch City to propose a ban.
content: The list of public nuisances in Salem, Mass., in high Halloween season is long and weird: Rowdy crowds imperiling 17th-century gravestones. Unlicensed fortune tellers. Skirmishes over parking spaces at Gallows Hill or the Museum of Torture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Jordyn Holman
title: Halloween Shoppers Not Spooked as Economic Slowdown Remains Elusive
description: From apple picking to skeleton cows, early seasonal spending seems solid. It’s the latest sign that Federal Reserve policy to combat inflation hasn’t slowed growth.
content: Economists spent much of 2023 warning that a recession could be imminent as the Federal Reserve raised interest rates to the highest level in more than two decades. But for companies like Soergel Orchards in western Pennsylvania, a slowdown is nowhere in sight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub and Matt Stevens
title: Matthew Perry, Star of ‘Friends,’ Is Dead at 54
description: He was known for playing the sarcastic but lovable Chandler Bing and for his struggles with drugs and alcohol, which he chronicled in a memoir.
content: Matthew Perry, who gained sitcom superstardom as Chandler Bing on the show “Friends,” becoming a model of the ability to tease your pals as an expression of love, has died. He was 54.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bonnie S. Glaser
title: No, Xi Jinping Is Not About to Attack Taiwan
description: The Chinese leader still has plenty of reason to doubt whether seizing Taiwan is worth the risks.
content: To some observers, it may seem like Xi Jinping is itching to unify Taiwan with China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norman Eisen and Amy Lee Copeland
title: Jenna Ellis Could Become a Star Witness Against Trump
description: She has given prosecutors a powerful tool.
content: When Jenna Ellis last week became the most recent lawyer to join in an accelerating series of guilty pleas in the Fulton County, Ga., prosecution of Donald Trump and his co-conspirators, she offered a powerful repudiation of the “Big Lie” that could potentially cut the legs out from under Donald Trump’s defense, make her a star witness for prosecutors and a potent weapon against the former president’s political ambitions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: ‘Nosferatu, a 3D Symphony of Horror’ Review: A Lip-Smacking Scare
description: This creepy Halloween show is the latest visual feat from Joshua William Gelb, presented by Theater in Quarantine and produced in a closet.
content: “Are you alone?” a disembodied voice asks softly. “Are you in a dark room? Have you locked your door?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Anthony Vidler, Architectural Historian Who Reshaped His Field, Dies at 82
description: He reached beyond conventional history to bring in perspectives from literary theory, philosophy and psychoanalysis.
content: Anthony Vidler, an architectural historian who, beginning in the 1960s, reshaped his field by setting aside dry chronologies of styles and movements for an interdisciplinary approach borrowing from psychoanalysis, French literary theory and cultural studies, died on Oct. 19 at his home in Manhattan. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Nolan, Eliza Fawcett and Nate Schweber
title: Protesters fill the streets in New York to support Palestinians in Gaza.
description: A large demonstration crossed the Brooklyn Bridge a day after Israel pushed into Gaza.
content: Crowds of pro-Palestinian demonstrators packed the streets of Brooklyn on Saturday as they called on the U.S. government to stop sending aid to Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Friends From Childhood. Brothers in War.
description: Three friends met as boys in western Ukraine. When Russia invaded, they enlisted in the same unit. There was comfort, and dread, in serving together.
content: At a gas station in western Ukraine, three men in their late 20s, friends since childhood, slid into plastic chairs. Exhausted and anxious, they began to sing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper and Benjamin Mullin
title: Tug-of-War Over N.B.A. Rights Provides Glimpse of Media’s Future
description: The league’s longtime television partners, including ESPN and Turner, are undergoing major changes, which could alter how games are watched.
content: The National Basketball Association’s season tipped off on Tuesday with stars like LeBron James and Nikola Jokic beginning the long quest for a title. But the action that will have longer-term ramifications for the league, and the media and entertainment landscape, is happening off the court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Netanyahu Apologizes After Blaming Security Chiefs for Failure in Hamas Attack
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who has not taken responsibility for Israel’s lapses in the Oct. 7 massacre, deleted a social media post in which he had pointed a finger at security agencies.
content: The rifts and disarray among Israel’s top leaders erupted into the open on Sunday when Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu appeared to blame the military and security establishment for the failures that led to the surprise Hamas assault on Oct. 7 — even as Israeli forces were broadening their ground war in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum

author: By David Marchese
title: Marina Abramovic Thinks the Pain of Love Is Hell on Earth
description: “I don’t see any good art made out of happiness,” says the legendary performance artist.
content: “I don’t see any good art made out of happiness,” says the legendary performance artist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Wu
title: Why Illegal Border Crossings Are at Sustained Highs
description: Shifting U.S. policies, global migration patterns and changing migrant demographics all contribute to record levels of border crossings.
content: Shifting U.S. policies, global migration patterns and changing migrant demographics all contribute to record levels of border crossings.
